@Diabb6 @rstats_tweets Do you really want the one versus all ROC curve results or is this just to average them to get a single value?

If it‚Äôs the latter, the default method does a multiclass ROC curve (from Hand and Till paper) or you can do macro- or micro-averaging estimates.
#rstats twitter, how would you get a vector or tibble with ROC AUC for each class in a multiclass problem, using the tidymodels ecosystem of packages?

@NaoyaTakedaAU You could also try arrow::open_dataset() or duckdb::duckdb_read_csv(). Both are crazy fast and don't require converting the file to SQL (although, converting the data to a parquet file should speed up reading). If you use an SQL-based solution, check out {dbplyr} for wrangling !

urls.title: Welcome | R for Data Science
urls.description: This book will teach you how to do data science with R: You‚Äôll learn how to get your data into R, get it into the most useful structure, transform it, visualise it and model it. In this book, you will find a practicum of skills for data science. Just as a chemist learns how to clean test tubes and stock a lab, you‚Äôll learn how to clean data and draw plots‚Äîand many other things besides. These are the skills that allow data science to happen, and here you will find the best practices for doing each of these things with R. You‚Äôll learn how to use the grammar of graphics, literate programming, and reproducible research to save time. You‚Äôll also learn how to manage cognitive resources to facilitate discoveries when wrangling, visualising, and exploring data.
